Alabama|Alaska|Arizona|Arkansas|California|Colorado|Connecticut|Delaware|District Of Columbia|Florida|Georgia|Hawaii|Idaho|Illinois|Indiana|Iowa|Kansas|Kentucky|Louisiana|Maine|Maryland|Massachusetts|Michigan|Minnesota|Mississippi|Missouri|Montana|Nebraska|Nevada|New Hampshire|New Jersey|New Mexico|New York|North Carolina|North Dakota|Ohio|Oklahoma|Oregon|Pennsylvania|Rhode Island|South Carolina|South Dakota|Tennessee|Texas|Utah|Vermont|Virginia|Washington|West Virginia|Wisconsin|Wyoming

Over the past several years, some local medical professionals have become reluctant to provide non-emergency health care services to Melmark clients in the absence of a guardianship order, except in the most serious emergencies. In Pennsylvania, once individuals reach the age of 18, they are presumed competent under the law unless a court has declared that individual to be incapacitated and appointed a guardian for that person. Therefore, unless a guardianship order has been issued by a court, the legal right of a parent or family member to direct medical care and other personal/financial issues of an adult child with a disability ends at age 18, no matter the level of the adult child with a disability, unless a court appoints the parent or family member as a guardian.

Although some health care providers will respect the wishes of the nearest family member on behalf of an individual with disabilities, a health care provider is under no obligation to do so, and such providers increasingly demand a guardianship order. Naturally, in circumstances where a resident is capable of providing competent decision-making, no guardianship is necessary, but where the level of mental retardation is more severe, it can be important for family members to consider guardianship proceedings.

In Pennsylvania, as in most other states, a limited guardianship is available so that the individual with disabilities retains as much decision-making as possible/appropriate given the abilities of that individual. If you should decide to pursue guardianship on behalf of your family member at Melmark, it would, of course, be necessary to pursue this matter with the assistance of your legal counsel, generally in the county from which the Melmark client came to Melmark. The costs of such a process vary, depending upon the geographic location of the county that would hear the matter. Naturally, Melmark respects the philosophies and wishes of family members and the individual with disabilities concerning this important decision.
Is there a court appointed legal guardian
Are there any restrictions on who may contact/visit applicant
